entry.title: “I think what the report shows is how reliant we are on fines...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“I think what the report shows is how reliant we are on fines and fees, so we can’t just pull the rug out in our budget,” Herod added. “But what we can do is limit its use and be very specific where we believe it will have the public safety effect that we want it to have.”

Last year the largest depository of justice system fees was the Judicial Stabilization cash fund, which supports court operating costs, judgeships and record sealing. Nearly $32 million went into that fund from civil docket fees and other court charges. The $50 monthly probation fee raised $19.1 million for probation and drug courts."

Colorado Politics

Colorado generated more than $132.8 million in fines and fees from criminal defendants and civil litigants. However, some people involved with justice policy believe that is too high of a

coloradopolitics.com

State took in over $132.8 million in criminal fines and fees in 2019

Colorado generated more than $132.8 million in fines and fees from criminal defendants and civil litigants. However, some people involved with justice policy believe that is too high of aColorado generated more than $132.8 million in fines and fees from criminal defendants and civil litigants. entry.title: “Gallegos said she had been hoping to announce that seven or...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Gallegos said she had been hoping to announce that seven or eight branches would open within two weeks. Instead, all she could say with certainty on Tuesday is that no branches would be reopening in the next two weeks and no target date for reopening had been set. She said library staff would continue to track data and consult with health officials before deciding on a reopening calendar.

“It’s really dependent on the direction the numbers are going,” she said.”

Denverite

Once the buildings are reopened, users will have to wear masks and will find sneeze guards at check-out and reference desks.

denverite.com

Denver libraries were going to reopen within weeks, but rising COVID-19 numbers put those plans on ice

Once the buildings are reopened, users will have to wear masks and will find sneeze guards at check-out and reference desks.Once the buildings are reopened, users will have to wear masks and will find sneeze guards at check-out and reference desks.

entry.title: “There was plenty of down-and-dirty fighting over a few of the...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“There was plenty of down-and-dirty fighting over a few of the proposals that Denver City Council referred to the ballot. This year, Denver voters can decide if they want to ante up for a cleaner environment, as well as tax themselves to provide more help for the homeless. They can give councilmembers more power in this strong-mayor town, and allow them to exercise some of that power virtually. And finally, they’ve got the chance to show the city’s three-decade-old pit bull ban the door.”

Denver Westword

Tax hikes and pit bulls are just the start.

westword.com

Here's What Denver Residents Will Be Voting On This Election

Tax hikes and pit bulls are just the start.Tax hikes and pit bulls are just the start.

entry.title: “A Denver-based hotline for Coloradans who need rental...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“A Denver-based hotline for Coloradans who need rental assistance and other housing help has doubled its staff and is working with new partners to meet needs created by the pandemic.

“Our call volume spiked through the roof in March,” said Patrick Noonan, who manages the Colorado Housing Connects hotline run by the nonprofit Brothers Redevelopment. The hotline serving the state can be reached at 844-926-6632.”

Denverite

Calls to a Denver-based hotline for Coloradans who need rental assistance spiked during the pandemic. Now, thanks to a state grant of nearly $1 million, it has more staff and new partners

denverite.com

A hotline that helps Coloradans with housing problems doubles its staff to keep up with the pandemic

entry.title: “Some medications are available to reduce the symptoms of...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Some medications are available to reduce the symptoms of sickle cell disease, but the only cure that’s approved in the United States is a bone marrow transplant, and there’s a roughly 5% of dying from treatment complications, said Dr. Chris McKinney, a pediatric hematology oncologist at Children’s.

Children’s and other hospitals are participating in a study testing a gene therapy treatment approved in Europe, but otherwise there have been few new options for patients since the first drug to reduce symptoms was approved in the 1990s, he said.”

The Denver Post

Some medications are available to reduce the symptoms of sickle cell disease, but the only cure that’s approved in the United States is a bone marrow transplant, and there’s a roughly 5…

denverpost.com

entry.title: “Burnout amongst health care workers, especially in the ICU...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“Burnout amongst health care workers, especially in the ICU pre-pandemic was at epidemic proportions already,” Anuj Mehta, a pulmonologist at National Jewish Health, told the station. “And it's only worse now. It's going to be a reckoning that we all have to face.”

The University of Colorado is now using federal grants to provide free mental health assistance for medical employees, including through support groups, individual counseling and a multipart series on resiliency.”

Colorado Politics

Healthcare workers in Colorado and elsewhere are warning about increased levels of stress, anxiety and burnout due to the COVID-19 pandemic, CPR reports.

coloradopolitics.com

Report: Pandemic contributing to burnout among healthcare workers

Healthcare workers in Colorado and elsewhere are warning about increased levels of stress, anxiety and burnout due to the COVID-19 pandemic, CPR reports.Healthcare workers in Colorado and elsewhere are warning about increased levels of stress, anxiety and burnout due to the COVID-19 pandemic, CPR reports.

entry.title: “The directive, right now, is set to expire on Oct. 12. At a...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“The directive, right now, is set to expire on Oct. 12. At a news conference on Friday, Polis said he will keep it going for at least another 30 days, urging Coloradans to abide by the mandate.

“Just wear a mask,” he said. “This is simple.”

The Colorado Sun

The directive is set to expire on Oct. 12. At a news conference on Friday, the governor said he will keep it going for at least another 30 days.

coloradosun.com

entry.title: “It’s a new era in technology for the community mental...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

“It’s a new era in technology for the community mental health center, a key step toward “preparing for the next generation,” said Alires Almon, the center’s director of innovation. The 12-week, virtual therapy program isn’t meant to replace traditional face-to-face counseling — it’s a contemporary option for people who would rather work on their mental health at home with their smartphone than walk into a mental health center.”

The Colorado Sun

The Mental Health Center of Denver is partnering with a health tech company to prepare for the next generation of therapy, happening on smartphones

coloradosun.com

Beyond Zoom: Virtual therapy’s next generation has Bluetooth pulse monitors and more

The Mental Health Center of Denver is partnering with a health tech company to prepare for the next generation of therapy, happening on smartphonesThe Mental Health Center of Denver is partnering with a health tech company to prepare for the next generation of therapy, happening on smartphones

entry.title: Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have...
entry.content:
Representative Leslie Herod

Incredibly humbled by this feature in 5280 and honored to have community support for this work. We all have a story to tell. Our stories are our strength and our voices will be heard.

"Forget political stereotypes: This history-making legislator is unapologetically progressive, is insistent that state government can be bipartisan (even now), and wants to transform the criminal justice system. And that's just the start of her ambitions.”

- 5280 Magazine
